fr.insa.rennes.info.chemical.backend
Class SubIndexProviderSolution

java.lang.Object
  fr.insa.rennes.info.chemical.backend.SubIndexProviderSolution
All Implemented Interfaces:
SubIndexProvider
public class SubIndexProviderSolution
extends java.lang.Object
implements SubIndexProvider

This class represents a sub index provider on a solution. That is to say that it does not simply iterates over 1 reagent, but several reagents. Moreover, it can also iterate on reagents in inner solutions, using a recursive structure (based on SubIndexProviderSolution and SubIndexProviderElement). Like all index providers, this sub index provider iterates overs elements in a given solution that we will call main solution. Note that a main solution can also be another solution's inner solution.

On contrary to a sub index provider on a simple element, this sub index provider has a quite complex structure. Basically, it handles a list of list of sub index providers.
In the first list, each entry corresponds to a sub solution in the main solution. For each one of these sub solution, a list of sub index provider is given. In the basic case, this list contains only instances of the SubIndexProviderElement class, one for each type of reagent searched in the sub solution. For example, if a reaction rule is requesting 2 integers and a string in a sub solution, if we consider that the main solution contains 2 sub solution, the list of list will be:
[ [SubIndexProviderElement(int), SubIndexProvider(int), SubIndexProvider(string)], [SubIndexProviderElement(int), SubIndexProvider(int), SubIndexProvider(string)] ]
In the general case, one or several SubIndexProviderSolution objects can be in the list. This case occurs when searching for elements in sub-sub-solutions (or deeper). The recursion then appears and everything is transparent for this sub index provider: the function called on the sub index providers of the lists is SubIndexProvider.increment(), and it will be called until it reaches an overflow. The implementation does not matter.

With this structure, this sub index provider is able to try EVERY combination of reagents for the reaction rule. The first level of the list of list of sub index provider is taken in order (that is to say, the sub solutions are considered one after the other), and each element in the second level is incremented (with SubIndexProvider.increment()) in the right order, until all the sub index provider reach the overflow. Then the next sub solution (next entry in the first level list) is tried, and so on. The overflow of this sub index provider is detected when all the sub solution were tested.

Author:
Cédric Andreolli, Chloé Boulanger, Olivier Cléro, Antoine Guellier, Sébastien Guilloux, Arthur Templé

SubIndexProviderSolution

public SubIndexProviderSolution(java.util.List<java.util.List<SubIndexProvider>> listSIP,
                                java.util.List<java.util.List<java.lang.Integer>> dependentIndexes)
Builds a sub index provider on a solution, with the given list of list of sub index provider, and the specified dependent indexes.

Parameters:
listSIP - The list of list of sub index provider (already fully built)
dependentIndexes - The dependent indexes. The structure is a list of list of integer because the is several set of dependent indexes

Returns the list of sub index providers of the currently tested sub solution.

init

public void init()
Initializes the sub index provider. Sets the lists indexes to 0, and call SubIndexProvider.init() on every sub index provider of the list.

Specified by:
init in interface SubIndexProvider

getValue

public int getValue()
Returns the index of the current sub solution tested.

Specified by:

Returns:
The index of the current sub solution tested.
See Also:
SubIndexProviderElement.getValue(), getValue()

increment

public boolean increment()
Increments the configuration of the indexes by one step. Tries to increment the sub index provider at [0] of the list [_currentSubSol], and if an overflow is detected on this sub index provider, it is is reported on the next sub index provider (just like a carry). When the "carry" has been reported correctly (that may take several steps/increments), just return false.When the carry can not be reported (_currentSubSol > number of sub solutions), that means a "general" overflow is detected: this sub index provider raises an overflow, and this function returns true

Specified by:
increment in interface SubIndexProvider
Returns:
true if an overflow was reached.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
Constructs and returns a string representing the sub index provider. The string representation consists in a list of the lists of sub index provider. Each sub list is enclosed in square brackets ("[]") and begins with its range in the first level list; each sub index provider is transformed in string with toString().

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
A string representing the sub index provider

getNumberOfElements

public java.math.BigInteger getNumberOfElements()
Computes the number of different combination of reagents possible. This number can be consequent (thus the BigInteger value returned). Basically, this function multiplies the value returned by SubIndexProvider.getNumberOfElements() for each sub index provider, and sums these values for all the sub solutions.

Specified by:
getNumberOfElements in interface SubIndexProvider
Returns:
the number of different combination of reagents possible

getNumberOfIncrements

public java.math.BigInteger getNumberOfIncrements()
Computes the number of increments that this sub index provider can (and must) perform. This number may differ from the number returned by getNumberOfElements(). This number can be consequent (thus the BigInteger value returned). Basically, this function multiplies the value returned by SubIndexProvider.getNumberOfIncrements() for each sub index provider, and sums these values for all the sub solutions.

Specified by:
getNumberOfIncrements in interface SubIndexProvider
Returns:
the number of increments that this sub index provider can (and must) perform.

isValid

public boolean isValid()
Returns true if the current state of the sub index provider is valid. A valid state is a state where there is no conflict between two dependent indexes. Two indexes are said dependent when they are pointing on the same type of object, in the same sub solution. For example, an index provider having two indexes pointing on the same integer in a given sub solution can not be valid (this integer would be considered as two integers in the reaction !).

Specified by:
isValid in interface SubIndexProvider
Returns:
true if the current combination of the sub index provider is valid.

merge

public void merge(SubIndexProviderSolution sipSol)
Merges two sub index provider on a solution in one. Used when building the whole index provider structure. Actually this functions just operates a merge of the lists (of lists) of sub index providers.

Parameters:
sipSol - The sub index provider on a solution that needs to be merged with this sub index provider.
